title: R45254
content: The Financial Services and General Government (FSGG) appropriations bill funds independent agencies in Title V, which manage federal real property, regulate financial institutions, and oversee mail delivery. The bill also includes provisions for the Department of the Treasury, Executive Office of the President, judiciary, and District of Columbia. Additionally, it addresses general provisions, Cuba sanctions, and mandatory retirement accounts. The FSGG appropriations bill funds independent agencies in Title V, managing federal real property, regulating financial institutions, and overseeing mail delivery. It also includes provisions for the Department of the Treasury, Executive Office of the President, judiciary, and District of Columbia. The bill funds mandatory retirement accounts in Title VI and occasionally addresses financial regulation issues in additional titles. Financial regulatory agencies are funded outside of the appropriations process. The House and Senate FSGG bills fund the same agencies, except for the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) funded through the Agriculture appropriations bill in the House and the FSGG bill in the Senate. President Trump submitted his FY2018 budget request on May 23, 2017. The CFTC funding is part of the total funding for FSGG independent agencies. President Trump's FY2018 budget requested $3.1 billion for independent agencies, including $330 million for the CFTC. The House Committee on Appropriations reported a bill with $253 million for FSGG agencies and $248 million for the CFTC in the Agriculture appropriations bill. This total of $501 million was significantly lower than the President's request, with the main difference in funding for the General Services Administration. The House of Representatives passed H.R. 3354, which included most of the text from H.R. 3280, with amendments totaling $488 million for FSGG independent agencies. The bill saw decreases in GSA funding and increases in SBA funding. The Senate Committee on Appropriations recommended $593 million for FSGG independent agencies in FY2018, significantly lower than the President's request, with the main difference in funding for the GSA. The FSGG independent agencies received $593 million in funding for FY2018, which was $2.5 billion below the President's request. Congress passed multiple continuing resolutions to provide funding based on FY2017 rates, with anomalies focusing on decreasing funding for the presidential transition. Additional funding of $127 million was included in the last resolution. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2018 (H.R. 1625 / P.L. 115-141) was enacted on March 23, 2018, with additional funding for the GSA and SBA to address disaster costs from hurricanes in 2017. The bill passed in the House on March 22, 2018, and in the Senate on March 23, 2018, with FSGG appropriations included in Division E. Division E, with the CFTC funded in the Agriculture appropriations in Division A. Additional legislative language affecting financial regulation is in Division S, Titles VIII and IX. FY2018 enacted appropriations in both P.L. 115-141 and P.L. 115-123 totaled $4.7 billion for the FSGG agencies, $1.6 billion above the original request, with much of this difference resulting from the emergency funding for the SBA. The GSA, FCC, and EAC also had substantial funding differences between requested and enacted amounts, with most of the EAC funding for grants to states for the election reform program. The FSGG appropriations bill provides funding for independent agencies overseeing various functions. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission is responsible for regulating derivatives markets. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) is an independent regulatory agency overseeing derivatives markets, including futures exchanges and swaps markets. Its functions include registration and supervision of industry personnel, prevention of fraud and price manipulation, and investor protection. Congressional jurisdiction remains with the House and Senate Agriculture Committees due to the market's historical ties to agriculture. Appropriations for the CFTC are under the Agriculture Appropriations Subcommittee in the House and the Financial Services and General Government Appropriations Subcommittee in the Senate. Following the financial crisis of 2008, reforms in the Dodd-Frank Act brought previously unregulated over-the-counter swaps markets under CFTC jurisdiction. This expanded the CFTC's oversight to include swaps markets with an estimated notional value of $240 trillion in the US, in addition to the already regulated futures and options markets with a $34 trillion notional value. The CFTC's jurisdiction covers regulated futures, options, and swaps markets with a total notional value of $274 trillion in the US. The President requested $250 million for the CFTC in FY2018, with appropriations varying slightly in different bills. The CPSC aims to reduce consumer harm from various products through safety standards, recalls, and consumer education. The CPSC conducts research on product safety, educates consumers about hazards, and collaborates with governments to establish regulations. The Trump Administration requested $123 million for the CPSC in FY2018, $3 million less than FY2017, with reductions in funding for specific programs and anticipated employee losses. The CPSC's budget request for FY2018 included $5.5 million for workforce development, $78.1 million for product safety, $31.3 million for research on hazards, and $8.1 million for communication. H.R. 3354 allocated $123 million for the CPSC, with $1.3 million designated for new grants. The House Appropriations Committee expects the CPSC to maintain grant funding at the FY2017 level. The House Appropriations Committee expects the CPSC to maintain grant funding at the FY2017 level of $1.3 million in FY2018. The committee also advised against adopting two proposed rules, one on voluntary recalls affecting small firms and the other on public disclosure of product hazards. The bill included provisions prohibiting the CPSC from finalizing certain rules until further studies are completed. The Senate draft bill allocated $123 million for the CPSC, while P.L. 115-141 appropriated $126 million for the CPSC. The Senate draft bill allocated $123 million for the CPSC, while P.L. 115-141 appropriated $126 million for the CPSC. The Election Assistance Commission (EAC) was established under the Help America Vote Act of 2002 (HAVA) and provides grant funding to states for election reform programs. The EAC also has responsibilities for testing voting machines and publishing studies on election issues. The Department of Justice enforces HAVA, and the President's budget request for FY2018 includes funding for these activities. The EAC, established under HAVA, has rulemaking authority and receives funding for election reform programs. The President's budget request for FY2018 included $9.2 million for the EAC, with $1.5 million transferred to NIST for voting system testing guidelines. P.L. 115-141 appropriated $10.1 million directly for the EAC, with additional funding for states to improve election administration. The FCC, an independent federal agency, receives its budget from regulatory fees collected by the agency. These fees, known as "Section (9) fees," are collected from license holders and deposited into an FCC account. The FCC has the authority to review and adjust the fees annually to reflect changes in its appropriation. In FY2018, the FCC requested a budget of $322 million. The FCC requested a budget of $322 million for FY2018, derived from regulatory fees. H.R. 3354 and the Senate draft bill both included this amount. P.L. 115-141 appropriated $322 million for the FCC, with an additional $600 million for the TV broadcaster relocation fund. The FDIC is funded through deposit insurance funds, including the Office of the Inspector General. The FDIC's Office of the Inspector General (OIG) is funded independently to ensure its independence. The President's FY2018 request included $39.1 million for the FDIC OIG, which was approved in P.L. 115-141. The FEC enforces campaign finance regulations and administers the presidential public financing system. The Federal Election Commission (FEC) oversees educational outreach, rulemaking, enforcement, and litigation, as well as issuing advisory opinions. The agency requested $71.25 million for FY2018, with most of the budget allocated to salaries, benefits, IT, and facilities expenses. Congress appropriated an additional $7.9 million in FY2017 for the FEC's office space relocation. The budget for the Federal Election Commission (FEC) is expected to cover salaries, benefits, IT, and facilities expenses. The FSGG legislation includes provisions related to campaign finance policy, such as prohibiting the SEC from disclosing political contributions and limiting trade association solicitations. P.L. 115-141 appropriated $71.25 million for the FEC. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) is responsible for protecting consumers from deceptive practices and promoting competition in various industries. It enforces laws, issues regulations, and educates consumers and businesses. Operating funds come from three sources. The FTC's operating funds come from direct appropriations, HSR filing fees, and DNC registry fees. In FY2017, direct appropriations accounted for 53.3% of the budget, HSR filing fees for 41.8%, and DNC registry fees for 5.0%. The President's FY2018 request included a budget cut, resulting in a total budget of $306.3 million, $6.7 million less than FY2017. The House Appropriations Committee directed the FTC to submit a report on its approach to enforcing privacy laws for consumer information collected by internet service providers and online services. They also requested a report on the consumer benefits of credit education services. The House Appropriations Committee directed the FTC to submit a report on the consumer benefits of credit education services and the impact of the Credit Repair Organizations Act on new credit education products. The Senate draft bill allocated $306.3 million for the FTC, with funding from various sources. The General Services Administration oversees federal procurement policies and property management. The General Services Administration (GSA) manages federal buildings, property disposal, and records. It oversees funding for former Presidents and presidential transitions through the Federal Buildings Fund (FBF), which is funded by rental payments from federal agencies leasing GSA space. Congress allocates FBF revenue for construction, repairs, rental payments, and other building expenses, with limitations on spending set by Congress. FBF funds can also be used to pay certain debts. GSA manages federal buildings and funding through the Federal Buildings Fund (FBF). FBF funds are allocated by Congress for construction, repairs, and other expenses. GSA's operating accounts are funded separately from the FBF. The total funding amount for GSA includes FBF appropriations and operating account appropriations. The President's FY2018 request, House-passed bill, Senate draft bill, and enacted amounts from P.L. 115-141 and P.L. 115-123 show varying proposed limits for GSA's real property activities. The President proposed $9.951 billion, the House passed $7.842 billion, the Senate draft bill $7.809 billion, and P.L. 115-141 provided $9.074 billion. The President's FY2018 request included $511 million for GSA's operating accounts, with $40 million allocated to the Asset Proceeds and Space Management Fund (APSMF) and $10 million for the Environmental Review Improvement Fund. These funds are designated for actions recommended by the Public Buildings Reform Board and activities related to reforming the environmental review process and the Federal Permitting Improvement Steering Council. The President's FY2018 request included $511 million for GSA's operating accounts, with funds allocated for reforming the environmental review process and the Federal Permitting Improvement Steering Council. The House-passed bill proposed $240 million for GSA's operating accounts, while the Senate draft bill suggested $234 million. P.L. 115-141 ultimately provided $335 million for GSA's operating accounts. The FY2018 appropriations for GSA's operating accounts were $81 million more than FY2017 and $176 million less than the President's request. Additionally, an extra $127 million was allocated in response to recent disasters. The FSGG appropriations bill funded four agencies with personnel management functions. The FLRA is an independent federal agency that administers and enforces Title VII of the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978, giving federal employees the right to join or form a union and bargain collectively over employment terms. Certain agencies are excluded from this statute for national security reasons. The FLRA is an independent federal agency that administers and enforces Title VII of the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978. It resolves disputes over bargaining units, unfair labor practices, and representation elections. The agency consists of a three-member authority, the Office of General Counsel, and the Federal Service Impasses Panel. The FLRA investigates unfair labor practices and manages regional offices. The President requested $26.2 million for FY2018, funding 121 FTEs. The MSPB is an independent agency adjudicating appeals and protecting the civil service merit system. The President requested $46.8 million for FY2018, funding 235 FTEs. The President's budget requested $46.8 million for FY2018 appropriations for the MSPB, including $44.5 million for salaries and expenses to fund 235 FTEs. The justification mentioned funding for a pay raise and IT infrastructure projects. The House, Senate, and P.L. 115-141 all approved the requested amount. The President's budget requested $148.3 million for OPM salaries and expenses in FY2018, including funding for IT infrastructure modernization, acquisition workforce capabilities, and trust fund transfers. OPM also requested an increase in FTE employment level to 6,376 for FY2018. The OPM requested an FTE employment level of 6,376 for FY2018, an increase of 500 FTEs from FY2017. The budget submission aims to address critical IT infrastructure needs, support oversight activities by the OIG, advance prescription drug audit programs, and provide oversight for IT infrastructure projects. The OIG will oversee the agency's IT infrastructure project, including data center consolidation and potential mainframe migrations. Appropriations for OPM include $129.3 million for salaries and expenses, $131.4 million for trust fund transfers, $5 million for OIG salaries and expenses, and up to $25 million for OIG trust fund transfers. The OPM salaries and expenses amount is $19 million less than the President's request. The Comptroller General must submit a report to Congress within six months evaluating OPM's cybersecurity measures, oversight of IT contractors, and compliance with government initiatives. The report also includes directives for OPM to modernize the federal retirement process. The House committee directed OPM to prioritize modernizing the federal retirement process, implement fully-automated electronic filing, secure personally identifiable information for security clearances, expedite security clearance processing, and provide biannual progress reports on the National Background Investigations Bureau. The House committee directed OPM to provide biannual progress reports on the National Background Investigations Bureau implementation plan, costs, governance, and staffing needs. OPM OIG must submit a report assessing NBIB implementation, costs, and governance structure within 12 months. The House committee also reminded OPM to prioritize critical agency functions. The House committee reminded OPM to prioritize critical functions such as recruitment, retention, and development of the federal workforce. OPM was directed to report on a plan to improve federal recruitment and hiring processes by reducing barriers and delays. Federal agencies are encouraged to increase recruitment efforts at various institutions. The committee also highlighted the CyberCorps Scholarship for Service Program. The House committee directed OPM to improve hiring of CyberCorps graduates and report on acquisition planning to enhance security clearance processes. OPM is directed to brief House and Senate Committees on Appropriations on actions taken to improve information security, continue providing reports on modernization efforts, and monthly progress reports on the retirement claims backlog. The House and Senate Committees on Appropriations receive progress reports on the retirement claims backlog, with mandatory appropriations for health benefits, life insurance, and retirement accounts. The Congressional Budget Office estimated specific amounts for these payments. The Office of Special Counsel (OSC) is an independent agency focused on protecting federal employees from prohibited personnel practices. The Office of Special Counsel (OSC) is a federal agency tasked with safeguarding the merit system by protecting federal employees and applicants from prohibited personnel practices, including reprisal for whistleblowing. The agency's budget request for FY2018 was $26.5 million, with an estimated FTE employment level of 144, an increase from the previous year. The funding was intended to address the rising demand for services, protect whistleblowers, and manage increasing case levels. The House passed H.R. 3354 with an appropriation of $24.7 million for VA and other agencies, slightly less than the President's request. The Senate draft bill and P.L. 115-141 allocated the requested amount. NARA, an agency overseeing government records, received $376 million in the President's FY2018 request, with H.R. 3354 allocating $380 million and the Senate draft bill proposing $403 million. P.L. 115-141 ultimately appropriated $403.2 million for NARA. The National Credit Union Administration (NCUA) manages the Community Development Revolving Loan Fund (CDRLF) to assist low-income credit unions in providing financial services to low-income communities. The CDRLF offers low-interest loans, deposits, and technical assistance grants, with earnings used to fund additional grants. Repayment periods for loans are typically five years. The CDRLF offers assistance grants to low-income credit unions for improving operations and addressing safety and soundness issues. The President requested no funding for the CDRLF in FY2018, but both H.R. 3354 and the Senate draft bill proposed $2 million, the same as in FY2017. P.L. 115-141 also appropriated $2 million. The Office of Government Ethics (OGE) is an independent federal agency established in 1978 to regulate financial disclosure, conflict of interest, and ethics in the executive branch. The Office of Government Ethics (OGE) is an independent federal agency established in 1978 to regulate financial disclosure, conflict of interest, and ethics in the executive branch. OGE provides education and training to executive branch ethics officials and does not adjudicate complaints or investigate matters within the jurisdiction of other authorities. The President's request for OGE in FY2018 was $16.4 million, which was appropriated by P.L. 115-141. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board (PCLOB) was reconstituted as an independent agency within the executive branch. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board (PCLOB) is an independent agency within the executive branch established by the Implementing Recommendations of the 9/11 Commission Act of 2007. Its role is to ensure privacy and civil liberties are considered in laws and policies related to terrorism protection, review their implementation, and analyze executive branch actions in balancing security and civil liberties. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board (PCLOB) advises the President and executive branch on privacy and civil liberties issues related to terrorism protection. The President requested $8 million for the PCLOB in FY2018, which was appropriated in P.L. 115-114. The PCAOB, created by the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, oversees audits of public companies and is funded through accounting support fees. It also administers a merit scholarship program for accounting students funded by penalties imposed by the PCAOB. Section 620 of a Senate draft bill would have allocated funds collected by the Board as of December 31, 2017. The PCAOB oversees public company audits and funds a scholarship program for accounting students through penalties. A Senate draft bill proposed allocating up to $1 million from penalties collected by the Board for scholarships. The SEC enforces securities laws to protect investors and maintain fair markets, with its budget determined through appropriations. The SEC's budget is funded through fees collected from securities exchanges, offsetting its appropriations under the Dodd-Frank Act. The President's FY2018 request was $1.85 billion, with additional funding for a new headquarters lease. The House passed $1.90 billion for the SEC in FY2018, while the Senate proposed $1.85 billion. The Dodd-Frank Act also established an SEC reserve fund for long-term expenses. The Dodd-Frank Act established an SEC reserve fund funded by registration fees, with a cap of $50 million per fiscal year. Any excess funds go to the Treasury Department. In FY2017, $25 million was rescinded from the fund. The President's FY2018 request would rescind $25 million, while the House proposed rescinding the entire $75 million in the fund. The Senate draft bill did not include rescinding funds from the SEC reserve fund. P.L. 115-141 appropriated $1.90 billion for the SEC, offset by fees. The House proposed rescinding $75 million from the SEC reserve fund, while the Senate draft bill did not include this provision. P.L. 115-141 allocated $1.90 billion for the SEC, with $245 million designated for the headquarters lease. The Selective Service System (SSS) is an independent federal agency responsible for conscripting personnel for military needs, but the draft was terminated in 1973. President Carter proposed standby draft registration in 1980. The Selective Service System (SSS) draft was terminated in 1973 and has not been renewed. President Carter proposed standby draft registration in 1980 for both men and women. Women can now serve in combat units. Funding for the SSS has remained stable in absolute dollars but decreased in inflation-adjusted funding. The Small Business Administration (SBA) administers programs to assist small businesses, including loan guarantees and low-interest loans. The Small Business Administration (SBA) provides assistance to small businesses through loan guarantees, low-interest loans, training programs, and advocacy within the federal government. The President requested $829.1 million for the SBA in FY2018, with allocations for salaries, entrepreneurial development, business loan administration, disaster assistance, and other expenses. The Administration requested funding for various programs including business loan subsidies, the Office of the Inspector General, the Office of Advocacy, and disaster assistance. Additionally, authorization levels were requested for loan guaranty programs and the Small Business Investment Company program. The House-passed bill would have appropriated $862.8 million for the SBA for FY2018, with allocations for salaries, entrepreneurial development, and noncredit programs. The House-passed bill allocated $862.8 million for the SBA for FY2018, with funds for salaries, entrepreneurial development, and noncredit programs. The Senate Committee on Appropriations recommended a draft bill with $886.3 million for the SBA, including increased funding for salaries and entrepreneurial development. The bill also included provisions for Microloan intermediaries to use more of their technical assistance grant funds on borrowers and third-party contracts. The SBA's final appropriation amount for FY2018 in P.L. 115-141 was $700.8 million, with allocations for salaries, entrepreneurial development, and noncredit programs. No funding was provided for disaster assistance as additional funds were allocated in P.L. 115-123 to address hurricane costs. The SBA was authorized to use $618.0 million of the supplemental funding for disaster assistance administrative costs. The U.S. Postal Service generates most of its funding through mail charges, with Congress providing appropriations for free mailing privileges. Congress authorized appropriations in the 1993 Revenue Forgone Reform Act, including a $29 million annual reimbursement until 2035 for lost revenue during the phase-in period. The Postal Service Fund, established under the PAEA in 2006, receives appropriations for USPS operations, USPSOIG, and PRC. The PAEA mandates direct budget requests to Congress and OMB for USPSOIG and PRC, funded from the Postal Service Fund. The Postal Service Fund, established under the PAEA in 2006, receives appropriations for USPS operations, USPSOIG, and PRC. In the FY2018 budget submission, the President requested $58.1 million for the Postal Service Fund, which is about $23.4 million more than the USPS's FY2017 appropriation. The President also requested $234.7 million for the USPSOIG, which is about $19 million less than the previous year. In FY2018, the President requested $234.7 million for the USPSOIG, which is $19 million less than its FY2017 appropriation. The House-passed bill would have provided $234.7 million, while the Senate draft bill would have allocated $245 million. P.L. 115-141 ultimately appropriated $245 million for the USPSOIG. The President requested $14.4 million for the PRC in FY2018, which is $1.8 million less than its FY2017 appropriation. The House-passed bill and Senate draft bill would have provided $15.2 million for the PRC. The House-passed bill included provisions such as requiring USPS to maintain six-day mail delivery, provide free mail for overseas voting and the blind, and prohibiting fees for child support agencies seeking addresses. It also prohibited the consolidation or closure of small rural post offices and directed the Postmaster General to report on efforts to increase sales of the Multinational Species semipostal stamp. The Postmaster General is required to submit a report on efforts to increase sales of the Multinational Species semipostal stamp. The Trump Administration proposes cost-reducing reforms for USPS, including adjusting mail delivery frequency and rate structures. Changes to USPS's retirement and retiree health benefits contributions are also suggested. The Trump Administration proposed cost-reducing reforms for USPS, including changes to retirement and retiree health benefits contributions. These reforms aimed to reduce the budget deficit by $46 billion over 10 years. P.L. 115-141 included some policy provisions but did not enact all of the President's requested reforms. The United States Tax Court (USTC) is an independent judicial body with jurisdiction over various tax matters. The United States Tax Court (USTC) is an independent judicial body with jurisdiction over tax matters. It is headquartered in Washington, DC, but judges conduct trials nationwide. The USTC was appropriated $51.2 million in FY2017, with varying amounts requested and appropriated in subsequent years. The FSGG Appropriations Act includes general provisions that are government-wide. The Administration's proposed government-wide general provisions for a fiscal year are generally included in the Budget Appendix. Among the new provisions proposed but not enacted for FY2018 were adjustments to the discretionary spending limit in certain categories. The FY2018 discretionary spending limits for all categories were outlined in the budget proposal and Senate draft bill. The DACA program would allow eligible aliens to work for the federal government. The Treasury Department's OFAC oversees the Cuba embargo regulations, which have been amended over the years. Provisions to tighten U.S. economic sanctions on Cuba were not included in the final bill. The proposed provisions to tighten U.S. economic sanctions on Cuba, including restrictions on importing confiscated property, were not included in the final bill. This measure aimed to prohibit the importation of rum and tobacco products by authorized U.S. travelers. The provision prohibits OFAC from licensing trademark registration fees for marks confiscated by the Cuban government without the original owner's consent. This relates to a dispute over the Havana Club trademark between a Cuban company and Bacardi Limited. OFAC issued a specific license for the Cuban company to renew the trademark, which was subsequently renewed until 2026 by the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office.
